Award.AwardTitle: BRAIN EAGER: Monitoring the Function of Individual Synaptic Contacts during Circuit Plasticity with Novel Optogenetic Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the primary challenges in neuroscience is to understand how sensory experiences drive the changes in brain circuits that underlie learning. Notably, the current lack of adequate tools to monitor the functional properties of individual synaptic connections has been holding back efforts to define how complex neuronal firing patterns drive changes in neuronal connectivity in the brain. This EAGER proposal is focused on the development and application of radically novel fluorescent probes to visualize integrated neural activity at individual synapses. If successful, these innovative probes will be transformative for the field; broad application of these probes by the neuroscience community will enable discovery of the rules that link sensory-driven neural activity to the structural changes in synaptic connectivity underlying learning. This knowledge would revolutionize current understanding of the dynamic changes in brain structure and function during learning. Furthermore, this project will foster close collaboration between groups of investigators with complementary expertise, and thus will create a vibrant environment for interdisciplinary training of the next generation of scientists.

This EAGER proposal addresses one of the major unsolved problems in neuroscience: how complex patterns of neural activity at multiple synapses interact to drive experience-dependent changes in circuit connectivity. The specific goal is to develop and apply novel fluorescent probes for visualizing the history of neural activity at individual synapses. These innovative probes will facilitate mapping the function and structure of the neural circuitry underlying a specific physiological process or behavioral task. To accomplish this goal, a multidisciplinary approach will be used that incorporates genetic strategies, computation-guided protein design, two-photon imaging, and electrophysiology. First, candidate sensors will be generated through a high-throughput, multi-step sensor screening process. Next, the sensitivity and kinetics of the sensors will be characterized in neurons in vitro, ex vivo, and in vivo. Finally, the sensors will be implemented in brain slices to probe the activity-dependent mechanisms that drive the formation and stabilization of synaptic connections. Ultimately, these sensors will be used to define the activity-dependent mechanisms that drive circuit changes in vivo during complex behavioral tasks. The proposed research would provide much needed imaging tools of synaptic activity that are compatible with a variety of advanced imaging techniques, such as wide-field, confocal and two-photon microscopy, and would dramatically enhance understanding of how the history of neural activity at individual synapses and their neighbors can influence long-term stability of neural circuit connections.

NSF1450932

BRAIN EAGER: Novel optogenetic sensors for monitoring the function of individual synaptic contacts during circuit plasticity

Project Outcomes Report

This primary goal of this EAGER proposal was the development and application of novel fluorescent probes to visualize the history of neural activity at individual synapses. The generation of these probes will transform our experimental capability to link the history of neural activity at single synapses to the activity- and experience-dependent changes in circuit connectivity that underlie complex behaviors, thus providing vital new information which will dramatically enhance our understanding of brain function.

This project had intellectual merit in that these experiments led the generation of two prototype glutamate sensors that 1) display appropriate kinetics to allow large-field recording of glutamate input in individual spines and 2) transform the activity of transient synaptic inputs into permanent labels of active synapses. These sensors hold great promise to enable new applications in studying the synaptic plasticity mechanisms that support learning and complex behaviors.

A first glutamate sensor variant, 49B3, which we categorized as a 'glutamate highlighter', showed a robust response to glutamate (450% ?F/F in green) in purified protein, similar to that of iGluSnFR. Notably, this variant can be efficiently converted to red form, where it displays also a robust response to glutamate (200% ?F/F). This variant is photostable when expressed in mammalian cells (HEK293) and displays a robust responses to glutamate (50% ?F/F in both red and green), which is comparable to a 80% ?F/F in green for iGluSnFR. We thus named this variant as a glutamate highlighter, which permits imaging the glutamate activity either in green or red. Notably, when characterized using glutamate uncaging onto single dendritic spines, we found that this variant exhibited a much slower decay that iGluSnFR, exhibiting a tau of ~300 ms, about ten-fold longer than iGluSnFR. This variant could thus be very useful for imaging individual synaptic release events, which have been difficult to reliably capture with iGluSnFR.

A second glutamate sensor variant, 45G10, which we categorized as a 'glutamate integrator, exhibited a 200% decreased green fluorescence with glutamate, and the green-to-red photoconversion rate was increased about 5-fold in the presence of glutamate. Therefore, variant 45G10 marked our first success to engineer a glutamate integrator. We tested this variant in mammalian cells (HEK293T), using a 405nm laser to photoconvert either in imaging media with 100 μM glutamate. The average red-to-green ratio of each selected cells in the presence of glutamate is significantly higher than that in the absence of glutamate. The significantly higher red-to-green ratio in the presence of 100 μM glutamate indicates that this prototype will be a valuable starting point for further evolution.

This project had broader impacts in that the PIs mentored one undergraduate student, two post-baccalaureate students, and one graduate student during the course of these studies. Furthermore, the PI was involved in a Brain Awareness Week outreach program at UC Davis that serves to advance public awareness about the progress and benefits of brain research and to encourage grade school students to choose scientific career paths. Each year the outreach program consisted of (1) grade school outreach, with a particular emphasis on local grade school with significant minority populations, and (2) a public neuroscience seminar series and interactive booths hosted at the Center for Neuroscience. This program has served to increase participation in outreach activities from a large and diverse group of students with the goal that they will be encouraged to continue outreach activities throughout their scientific careers.
